comments.commentBody: Russian ships didn't stop dead in the water as you described; this is a myth that has been disproven.

Was Kennedy's threat of force to stop Soviets ships with missiles headed for Cuba the reason why World War III didn't occur or was it Nikita Khruschev's recognition that firing at U.S. Naval warships could start the conflagration as his ships stopped dead in the water as they neared Cuban ports?

This situation in 1962 during the Cuban Missile Crisis is instructive as it contains face saving, the client state, the threat of force and most of all, uncertainty over what the other side will do.

Diplomacy at the UN with Ambassador Stevenson's dramatic proof of Soviet missiles in Cuba ultimately provided a mutually beneficial way out for both Kennedy and Khruschev.

Perhaps Obama and Putin should step back and review this crisis from 1962 to figure a way forward in Syria. While there are differences worth noting, including the stakes much higher in 1962, the ultimate, sobering solution was diplomacy.
Or to dictatorial rule!

I find the arguments for military intervention increasingly unpersuasive. Whether people die as the result of sarin-filled missiles or US navy cruise missiles, they are still dead. If we are unable to intervene with massive humanitarian assistance then we are unable to make any positive contribution. The way to peace is peace.

Elections to the american way? That's not democracy! Let any country to deal with its on issues. Who invaded the US when the slaved their own black people? Who is invading US when its goverment is invading privacy of their own people?
Because that always works well.

The power of propaganda is that most of what you say is unassailable truth.

Look for what he didn't say.

If Putin wants to let the Syrian's decide their fate peacefully, he should force Assad out, and work to stabilize country so elections to be held in 18-24 months.
Why is it *obviously* specious to consider that the rebels did the chemical attack? They are the ones who would benefit the most by drawing the USA into their war.

Not a big fan of Putin, however beliefs and actions don't always go together (do they ever in our personal and political lives?) . I remember that not so long ago blacks were less  "equal" than whites in our  exceptionally holy country. Maybe it would serve us better to see  our own spots before we point the finger  to others

Thank you Mr. Putin for the attempt to prevent turmoil. It requires foresight, character and very good motivation to actually 'see' what you are talking about. There's a strong need for international leaders to desist from being populist just for the sake of it and adopt a more mature stand. Pride is another thing but if we look back into historical blunders, the feeling of superiority is right there at the top and belies lack of universalism and which underlines a true international leader. There is a saying in sanskrit 'Vasudaiv kutumbhakam' which is the golden rule and translates to 'the whole world is a family'.
He certainly has no vested interest in making false or misleading arguments. Your naivete is rather surprising considering we are discussing essentially an authoritarian leader here.

Putin just says common sense. That's it.
Once the first shot as fired - forget about 'limited and targeted strike'. There are too many countries in the region who may get involved,
It would be nice to see the evidence one way or the other. The 'trust us Assad did it' from Secty Kerry is not convincing.

"Let us not forget that Putin clearly can not be trusted because he denied these chemical weapons being used in Syria less than a week ago, and all of a sudden, he comes out and says he will get rid of them."

Putin hasn't denied that chemical weapons were used: "No one doubts that poison gas was used in Syria." He just thinks the rebels did it, not Assad. Nor has he ever suggested that Syria doesn't have chemical weapons.

Putin says two much different things: (1) in his opinion, Assad didn't carry out the CW attack (which may or may not be true – but let's face it: the US' claim has no more evidence to support it than Putin's does); and (2) regardless of who carried out the CW attack, Syria's willingness to give up its chemical weapons is a big step in the right direction, and we all should encourage that.

That's all he's saying, and he's not saying what you claim.

and what do you know, about the will of the people in Syria?
who is fighting in SSA, how do you think?

Nice words Putin. But you do not support the will of the people in Syria since you give weapons and cover to the guy who slaughters them. This was all quite peaceful in the beginning.

So spare us please. If you want to help, get Assad to step down and support an interim government while the country prepares for elections.

You defense of Assad shows your moral position quite clearly.
Doesn't USA sell weapons to all the rest of the world?
Yeah, well, Obama's a big liar: http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/cia-begins-weapons...
does anyone really believe that the USA is not supplying weapons to the opposition?

While I found some of what Mr. Putin said agreeable, the following statement is pretty ridiculous given Russia's role as Syria's main arms supplier.

"This internal conflict, fueled by foreign weapons supplied to the opposition, is one of the bloodiest in the world."

He forgot to mention that Russian made weapons have helped Assad kill thousands of his own people.

Considering the immense distances to the stars, even the nearest star Proxima Centauri (at 4.3 light years or about 25 trilliion miles away, suggests an interesting perspective.

If we want to calculate, for astrological purposes, the relationships between stars and people born "under" them, it's obvious that the distances between say NY and London or Melbourne Australia are infinitesimal compared to stellar distances. What this means is that every human on earth is effectively born "under" the same stars.

Even time fades away. The relationships between any particular group of stars and terrestrial locations are mathematically the same today as they were 50 years ago.

In other words, every place on earth has a virtually identical relationship to any grouping of stars--say the stars that make up the constellation Taurus the Bull. The only thing that varies is the orientation--facing toward or away--which is the result of the 24 hour rotation of the earth itself.

A case can be made for the relative changes of the sun, moon and planets in relation to any terrestrial birth places but that's as far as one can go astrologically.

Not to put too fine a rhetorical point on it, but, yes, "winners" IMPLIES "losers."  Anything/everything else is just a reshuffling of the status quo.  When government passes laws that advantage an individual or group (corporations), it creates the potential for re-organizing who is a winner and who is a loser.  An easy example would be when an industry that is highly polluting leaves the clean-up costs of its manufacturing processes to be borne by the populace at large, while the profits from the sale of the results of those manufacturing processes go into private hands - with no further societal liability.  Very little of what we call the "free market" is actually a "free" market untainted by outside influences, and since to me that seems indisputable, shouldn't we be spending more time looking at the potential social liability of those free markets?

What do you mean, with Bill Gates there were no "big losers?" Of course there were. His product actually was not that exceptional, as many people in the tech world will tell you. There were far better products---he was smart and visionary, but he was also ruthless and lucky, and the world missed out on better technology in part because of his brazen and successful efforts to construe monopolies. Microsoft severely stifled competition, and though we'd like to believe the best products win out, that simply has not been true.

He got in early and quick, and we're still saddled with bizarrely ill-designed software, while better products fell by the wayside.

He destroyed one company after another in order to reign supreme, decimated small businesses that were trying to compete (one competitor committed suicide, though you obviously can't blame that directly on Gates), and forced the development of information technology in a direction that favored him and thwarted far superior efforts. He leveraged his company's money and power to force hardware firms (IBM, etcetera) to bundle all of his own products and exclude all others.

There were many big losers, the public included.

So, when one company buys out another company and subsequently lays off 50% of the workers, thereby impoverishing them, this doesn't matter?  Oh, I forgot--you only consider two parties to the transaction and the workers are the third party.  But the thing that Henry Ford understood so well, but today's ideologues don't know or won't admit, is that without reasonable wages, workers can't purchase goods.

"Big winners beget big losers."

Fundamentally wrong. That might be the case in a poker game,but not in the economy. In a voluntary transaction, both parties win. Put differently, Bill Gates was a "big winner"; there were no "big losers" (save, perhaps, Wang.)

This piece demonstrates the absolutely absurd way leftists view the economy: as a zero sum game, in which for A to "win", B must "lose". Utter, absolute nonsense.

No one is poor because others possess the "freedom to amass personal wealth." Quite the contrary; without that freedom, EVERYONE would be poor.

Indeed, in a paper legendary for its economic illiteracy -- often spouted by those with PH.D.s in economics -- this might just be the silliest piece ever. A more thorough misunderstanding of basic economics would be hard to imagine. Even the Onion would face a difficult time satirizing this effort.

It makes perfect sense to expect everyone to earn that which they want. Otherwise, someone else has to earn it for them, and no one, individually or collectively, has the legitimate right to demand the fruits of someone else's labor.

"Economic justice" is a fairly easy concept: you should receive that which you earn in voluntary transactions. And not one penny more.

SD, Yes indeed.

I went with a friend to the Occupy marchs in our town a couple of years ago. We weren't the oldest there, but close to it.

We preached. We told the youngsters that when we went to university it was almost free, and it was. And there were grants, not loans.

We told them to lobby for more funding for education. We were told by current students that they were very afraid that what they were studying would not get them jobs. We told them, we never gave that a thought, and that is true too. We also told them to think a bit smarter. I pushed the idea that any skill in healthcare, from instrument technician to nurse to social worker to accountant to economic administration was the job of the future. My friend pushed green energy alternatives. We both pushed for creative thinking, and I think we were both right.

It is a lot harder now. Mostly because the governments we have now do not feel that they are accountable to the whole of their own populations, only 1%.

I don't know where it will end up, but I am already grieving for what was.

Dale,

Thanks for reminding us. At times, I guess we can get lost in things that have little consequence, when the real issues lay unattended.

I think that sort of wording is getting a bit nit-picky at this point of the game to be honest.  What do you think?  I agree with you on your points and being created exceptional, does not mean that we all manage to maintain the trait.  I would love to see Obama write a response piece as you mentioned as well.
I think that you forgot to put quotation marks around leader

I took President Obama's use of the word 'exceptional' as a reminder that any exceptionalism is based on the principles on which our country was founded, countering an attitude in some quarters of our country that we're exceptional because we're us. Perhaps Mr. Putin was unaware of this.

It seems a disrespectful to our leader (and hence us) to chide him so, although if this were intended to initiate a back-and-forth, and President Obama may now address the Russian people in an uncensored Russian newspaper, that would be very interesting.

The difference is that Putin still needs to strive for influence to hold on to power in his "democracy finding its way."  Obama, on the other hand, does not face reelection and can negotiate the situation without grandstanding.
Okay, this is getting weird. Twice, in the last four days, Putin has demonstrated real diplomatic talent and  sounded smarter and better informed than Obama.
Hilarious
Putin said things that Obama could not say, and Obama said things that Putin could not say. They make a great team, and the future looks brighter for the world because of it.

My experience utterly, decades ago. In the aggregate, the rich kids (certainly with some exceptions) did not seem as smart or as interested in knowledge as we were. It wasn't that cool in their circle, and it really didn't matter to their future. In turn, after an initial period of adjustment, most of us did not feel we were missing very much by not being in their social sphere.

The socioeconomic elite go to college for connections and affirmation of their status. The middle class go for cerification, in the hope of keeping from slipping down economically. The lower middle class and poor who are fortunate enough to go are trying to crawl out of a hole with steeper walls than they - or most of us - realize. And a few from each class love knowledge, or better still, find that love.
Too bad the American People haven't learned to apply it to themselves yet.
No, individual freedom does not make America exceptional, at least not in this century. Travel to most other places in the developed world.
The Founders believed that the individual was a 'him" in terms of any "governing" and gave no role whatsoever to "her." Unfortunately, there was nothing exceptional about that at the time.

Neither Obama nor Putin know what American Exceptionalism is.

American Exceptionalism has nothing to do with being better than any one. The Founders and their successors believed that in America, the individual governs him or herself. And that’s what makes America exceptional.

The worst hairstyle seen on a national team since Sir Bobby Charlton's comb-over retired.

-- Brian

You didn't give credit for
im Howard's beard.

I agree with you. I thought Mexico had much better of the play in the first half, and Brian doesn't downgrade Beasley for a shanked clearance that required the best save that Howard made, and early on enough to make a real difference in the match?
The passing was poor. The US had four scoring opportunities in the entire match: The two corners for EJ headers, one saved in the first half on the line by Corona, and the one early in the second half where Corona came, and came up two yards short, leaving EJ for an uncontested headed goal. The Diskerud skill that led to the cross that Donovan potted was sublime, and then there was the PK.
Other than those moments, the American passing was pretty dismal.
But once the USMNT scored, Mexico folded like the proverbial $2 suitcase.

If Panama can hold Mexico to a draw at the Aztec in the next round, then Mexico would need a better result than Panama (at Costa Rica while Panama is at US) just to make the intercontinental playoff. Might the US help Panama to hurt Mexico?

Marty, agree with you 100% .  Also grew up on Phil, White and Messer - and how they would alternate every three innings between radio, TV play-by-play and TV color (except for Rizzuto who would leave early to beat the traffic on the GW Bridge).  And I also remember Sterling's hockey broadcasts (think he did the Islanders for awhile also) - and thought he was terrible back then, just sounded so forced and contrived.  He also did the Nets, and tried to come up with an equivalent to Marv Albert's "Yes" - it was so bad I forgot what it was, lol.  I rarely listen to the games on radio now; sure hope they make a change.

I've enjoyed watching Jeter's fluid moves at SS ever since he first took over the spot.   Whenever the ball went his way I'd think, "money in the bank", and he'd inevitably make the play look easy; effortless and smooth.   To hell with his range, or supposed lack thereof, the guy made plays, thousands of them.  He reminds me of another great smooth player of this generation, albeit this guy plays on a tennis court and is named Federer and he got bounced at the US Open last week well before the quarterfinals, a tournament he practically owned in the mid 2000's.   Federer's fall from the top reminds me a great deal of what's going on with Jeter and his Yankees who are now struggling and straining to just make the playoffs, which is looking more doubtful by the day.    I had hoped to watch Jeter take a serious run at Pete Rose's all time hits record over the next five years.   I was also hoping to see Federer win 25 grand slam titles.   I fear these two once in a generation players have seen their better days and will have to settle for being the greatest of their generations.    Not bad for them and fantastic for us who got to watch them when they were at their best.

I think Obama should just follow Putin and Russia's lead when  developing U. S. foreign policy.  What could possibly go wrong?  I'm sure Putin has America's best interest as his top priority.  Plus it's obvious he is far wiser than Obama regarding world affairs.
